At-a-Glance: Top-bar hives prioritise low-lift, foundationless beekeeping. Success relies on straight-draw management, gentle inspections, and cautious harvest handling.
Why it Matters: Lower ergonomic load and minimal equipment costs.
Natural comb requires more attention to spacing and handling.
Objectives: Keep combs straight and supported during build.
Time harvests to avoid comb collapse and robbing.
Adapt varroa and nutrition plans to non-modular frames.
What Good Looks Like: Guide strips on bars; frequent alignment checks during build.
Crush-and-strain harvest from outer honey combs; brood nest undisturbed.
Varroa monitored and treated with methods compatible with TBH hardware.
Step-by-Step: 1) Setup: level stand; bars with guides; follower boards for cavity control.
2) Early season: place empty bars between straight combs to guide draw.
3) Inspections: lift carefully by bar ends; avoid tilting soft comb in heat.
4) Harvest: take capped honey combs away from brood; handle in cool room; avoid drips.
5) Varroa: use OA dribble/vapor or other compatible options; track counts.
6) Wintering: condense space with followers; ensure dry lid and adequate stores.
Seasonality & Climate: Heat softens new comb; inspect in cooler hours.
Humid climates demand excellent ventilation without drafts.
Data & Thresholds: Do not cut/harvest until fully capped for moisture control.
Maintain enough stores contiguous to the cluster for winter.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: Cross-comb -> Cut and realign early; add guides; tighten spacing.
Symptom: Comb collapse -> Inspect earlier/cooler; reduce bar spans; harvest less at once.
Symptom: Backfilling -> Add bars/follower adjustments; encourage new draw near brood.
Common Pitfalls: Harvesting uncapped comb leading to fermentation.
Skipping varroa monitoring due to non-standard frames.
Tools & Techniques: Guide strips, follower boards, comb knives, crush-and-strain kit.
OA dribble/vapor kits compatible with TBH.
Safety & Compliance: Mark hive type in records for tailored inspections.
Communications: Explain TBH differences to helpers to prevent rough handling.
Further Reading: Case studies comparing TBH and framed hives.
Notes: Keep a ‘cool chain’ for comb transport in hot weather.
